Title: Efferent connections of the cingulate gyrus in the rhesus monkey
Abstract: Efferent cortical connections of the cingulate gyrus are investigated in rhesus monkey using autoradiographic technique. The results indicate that the rostralmost part of the cingulate gyrus (area 32) sends projections to the lateral prefrontal and midorbitofrontal cortex and to the rostral portion of the superior temporal gyrus. In contrast, the other two major subdivisions of the cingulate gyrus, areas 24 and 23, have widespread connections within the cortex. Area 24, for example, projects to the premotor region (areas 6 and 8), the fronto-orbital cortex (area 12), the rostral part of the inferior parietal lobule, the anterior insular cortex, the perirhinal area and the laterobasal nucleus of amygdala. Area 23, likewise, sends its connections to the dorsal prefrontal cortex (areas 9 and 10), the rostral orbital cortex (area 11), the parieto-temporal cortex (posterior part of the inferior parietal lobule and the superior temporal sulcus), the parahippocampal gyrus (areas TH and TF), the retrosplenial region and the presubiculum. It seems that the connections of the rostralmost part of the cingulate gyrus resemble the efferent cortical connectional patterns described for lateral prefrontal and orbito-frontal cortex, whereas the projections of areas 24 and 23 are directed to the neocortical, the paralimbic and the limbic areas.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Likewise, the caudal limit of the cingulate gyrus extends beyond the splenium of the corpus callosum and merges with Brodmann's (1909) area 7 dorsally and area 19 ventrally." (p. 320) " Parietal projections are directed primarily to the lateral and medial parts of area 7 (or area PG of Bonin and Bailey)." (p. 326)
@InterMapRelations.Corrected_Why:
"Likewise, the caudal limit of the cingulate gyrus extends beyond the splenium of the corpus callosum and merges with Brodmann's (1909) area 7 dorsally and area 19 ventrally." (p. 320) " Parietal projections are directed primarily to the lateral and medial parts of area 7 (or area PG of Bonin and Bailey)." (p. 326)
This text is misinterpreted: PG is not equal to area 7, byt to lateral and medial parts of area 7.
So the relation should be an S.

@InterMapRelations.Comments: Areas 11-13 of PVM81 seem to be identical with areas 11-13 of W40, because (i) they have the same abbreviations, (ii) the same locations, (iii) W40 is a classic reference for the description of the orbitofrontal cortex, and (iv) because Pandya et al. ('81) have cited W40 for the definition of areas 10 and 14.

Areas 11-13 of PVM81 seem to be identical with areas 11-13 of W40, because (i) they have the same abbreviations, (ii) the same locations, (iii) W40 is a classic reference for the description of the orbitofrontal cortex, and (iv) because Pandya et al. ('81) have cited W40 for the definition of areas 10 and 14.

Areas 11-13 of PVM81 seem to be identical with areas 11-13 of W40, because (i) they have the same abbreviations, (ii) the same locations, (iii) W40 is a classic reference for the description of the orbitofrontal cortex, and (iv) because Pandya et al. ('81) have cited W40 for the definition of areas 10 and 14.

" In the frontal cortex, terminal label was observed over area 9, dorsal to the principal sulcus, and along both the rostral and caudal banks of the arcuate sulcus (areas 8 and 6, rspectively)." (p. 322)
Based on this citation of PVM81 it is not unambiguously possible to decide, from which parcellation scheme they are taken from. Both W40 and B09 are possible, because they are both classic maps for the description of the frontal cortexs. Differences between both maps are for example (i) that area 8 of W40 is located both medially and laterally, but area 8 of B09 is only located laterally, and (ii) W40 divides his area 8 in 8A and 8B in opposite to B09.
Because area 8 is only used in its entity without subdivisions like area 8A&B of W40, it can be seen as a hint, that Brodmann's ('09) areas 6, 8, and 9 were used and not Walker's ('40).

" In the frontal cortex, terminal label was observed over area 9, dorsal to the principal sulcus, and along both the rostral and caudal banks of the arcuate sulcus (areas 8 and 6, rspectively)." (p. 322)
Based on this citation of PVM81 it is not unambiguously possible to decide, from which parcellation scheme they are taken from. Both W40 and B09 are possible, because they are both classic maps for the description of the frontal cortexs. Differences between both maps are for example (i) that area 8 of W40 is located both medially and laterally, but area 8 of B09 is only located laterally, and (ii) W40 divides his area 8 in 8A and 8B in opposite to B09.
Because area 8 is only used in its entity without subdivisions like area 8A&B of W40, it can be seen as a hint, that Brodmann's ('09) areas 6, 8, and 9 were used and not Walker's ('40).

" In the frontal cortex, terminal label was observed over area 9, dorsal to the principal sulcus, and along both the rostral and caudal banks of the arcuate sulcus (areas 8 and 6, rspectively)." (p. 322)
Based on this citation of PVM81 it is not unambiguously possible to decide, from which parcellation scheme they are taken from. Both W40 and B09 are possible, because they are both classic maps for the description of the frontal cortexs. Differences between both maps are for example (i) that area 8 of W40 is located both medially and laterally, but area 8 of B09 is only located laterally, and (ii) W40 divides his area 8 in 8A and 8B in opposite to B09.
Because area 8 is only used in its entity without subdivisions like area 8A&B of W40, it can be seen as a hint, that Brodmann's ('09) areas 6, 8, and 9 were used and not Walker's ('40).

It seems, that area TF of PVM81 is identical with area TF of BB47 because (i) they have the same abbreviation, (ii) the same location and (iii) BB47 have been already cited for the dsecription of another area , i.e. area TH of BB47.

" In case 1, the injection involved areas 10 and 32, whereas in 
case 2, area 32 and the rostralmost part of area 25 were labeled.
In both cases the distribution of labeled axons and their patterns of termination were similar. " (p. 321)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments: Labeled areas in case 2 were not illustrated; they are only described textually in combination with case 1.

publication.title: Efferent connections of the cingulate gyrus in the rhesus monkey
publication.abstract: Efferent cortical connections of the cingulate gyrus are investigated in rhesus monkey using autoradiographic technique. The results indicate that the rostralmost part of the cingulate gyrus (area 32) sends projections to the lateral prefrontal and midorbitofrontal cortex and to the rostral portion of the superior temporal gyrus. In contrast, the other two major subdivisions of the cingulate gyrus, areas 24 and 23, have widespread connections within the cortex. Area 24, for example, projects to the premotor region (areas 6 and 8), the fronto-orbital cortex (area 12), the rostral part of the inferior parietal lobule, the anterior insular cortex, the perirhinal area and the laterobasal nucleus of amygdala. Area 23, likewise, sends its connections to the dorsal prefrontal cortex (areas 9 and 10), the rostral orbital cortex (area 11), the parieto-temporal cortex (posterior part of the inferior parietal lobule and the superior temporal sulcus), the parahippocampal gyrus (areas TH and TF), the retrosplenial region and the presubiculum. It seems that the connections of the rostralmost part of the cingulate gyrus resemble the efferent cortical connectional patterns described for lateral prefrontal and orbito-frontal cortex, whereas the projections of areas 24 and 23 are directed to the neocortical, the paralimbic and the limbic areas.
